gruut.const module¶

Shared classes, types, and enums

class gruut.const.Sentence(raw_text='', raw_words=<factory>, clean_text='', clean_words=<factory>, tokens=<factory>, phonemes=None)¶

Bases: object

Tokenized and cleaned sentence

clean_text: str = ''¶

Text after being processed (i.e., abbreviations/numbers expanded)

clean_words: Sequence[str]¶

Words after being processed. Derived from tokens.

phonemes: Optional[Sequence[Sequence[str]]] = None¶

Optional phonetic pronunciations for tokens. Added by phonemizer.

raw_text: str = ''¶

Original text before any processing

raw_words: Sequence[str]¶

Words from original text before any processing

tokens: Sequence[gruut.const.Token]¶

Tokens with optional features (e.g., part of speech)

class gruut.const.Token(text, features=<factory>)¶

Bases: object

Single token

features: MutableMapping[str, str]¶

Optional token features (e.g., part of speech).

Keys are feature names, such as those in TokenFeatures.

Values are assigned by models like those in gruut.pos or gruut.g2p.

text: str¶

Text value of token

class gruut.const.TokenFeatures(value)¶

Bases: str, enum.Enum

Commonly used token features

PART_OF_SPEECH = 'pos'¶

Part of speech tag, typically chosen from Universal Dependencies

class gruut.const.WordPronunciation(phonemes, preferred_features=<factory>)¶

Bases: object

Single pronunciation for a word

phonemes: Sequence[str]¶

List of phonemes for this pronunciation

preferred_features: MutableMapping[str, Set[str]]¶

Features that cause this word pronunciation to be preferred.

Keys are feature names, such as those in TokenFeatures.

Values are sets of compatible feature values, for example part of speech tags. When choosing among several pronunciations for a Token, the one with more compatible features will be chosen.

gruut.g2p module¶

Grapheme to phoneme prediction using python CRF suite.

For training, requires pre-aligned corpus in Phonetisaurus format. https://github.com/AdolfVonKleist/Phonetisaurus

class gruut.g2p.GraphemesToPhonemes(crf_tagger, eps_phoneme='_', phoneme_join='|')¶

class gruut.phonemize.SqlitePhonemizer(database_path, token_features=None, use_word_indexes=False, word_index_pattern=re.compile('^(.+)_(\\\\d+)$'), word_break=None, ipa_minor_breaks=True, minor_breaks=None, ipa_major_breaks=True, major_breaks=None, lookup_with_only_words_chars=False, non_word_chars_pattern=re.compile('\\\\W'), use_features=True, fail_on_unknown_words=False, cache_pronunciations=True, lexicon=None, g2p_model=None, feature_map=None, remove_stress=False)¶

Bases: gruut.phonemize.Phonemizer

Full-featured phonemizer with sqlite database lexicon backend.

Pipeline is (roughly):

  1. Cache is checked first for exact word, then filtered word (non-word chars stripped)

  2. Database is checked first for exact word, then filtered word

  3. Pronunciations are guessed with self.guess_pronunciations

  4. The best pronunciation is:

    • The Nth pronunciation if a word index is provided (1-based)

    • The pronunciation with the highest count of matching features (e.g., part of speech)

    • The first pronunciation

    • Guessed using pre-trained gruut.g2p model

database_path¶

Path to sqlite3 database

token_features¶

List of feature names that tokens should have. Automatically populated from an existing database.

use_word_indexes¶

Allow words of the form “word_N” where N is the 1-based pronunciation index

word_index_pattern¶

Regex used to group words into text (first group) and pronunciation index (second group).

word_break¶

Phoneme string to insert between words (e.g., “#” for IPA)

ipa_minor_breaks¶

If True, replace minor breaks with gruut_ipa.IPA.BREAK_MINOR symbol. If False, the original symbol is used (e.g., “,”)

minor_breaks¶

List of minor break symbols, or mapping from symbol to phonemes (e.g. {“,”: “|”}). Minor breaks are short pauses in a sentence.

ipa_major_breaks¶

If True, replace major breaks with gruut_ipa.IPA.BREAK_MAJOR symbol. If False, the original symbol is used (e.g., “.”)

major_breaks¶

List of major break symbols, or mapping from symbol to phonemes (e.g. {“.”: “‖”}). Major breaks are between sentences.

lookup_with_only_words_chars¶

If word cannot be found in lexicon, strip non-word characters from it and try again

non_word_chars_pattern¶

Regex pattern used to strip non-word characters from a word

use_features¶

If True, multiple pronunciations are disambiguated using token and word pronunciation features. The best pronunciation has the most preferred features matching the token.

fail_on_unknown_words¶

If True, phonemization will raise an UnknownWordError if a word does not have a pronunciation

cache_pronunciations¶

Pronunciations are cached in-memory when looked up in the database or guessed

lexicon¶

Pre-existing lexicon used to augment database (modified by phonemizer)

g2p_model¶

Path to pre-trained grapheme-to-phoneme model. See also: gruut.g2p

feature_map¶

Mapping from feature name (e.g. “pos”) to a mapping from raw feature values to normalized values (e.g., “NNS”: “NN”). Used to simplify the feature values needed in the lexicon to disambiguate pronunciations.

remove_stress¶

If True, remove stress characters when loading/guessing prounciations

NON_WORD_CHARS_PATTERN = re.compile('\\W')¶

Pattern to match non-word characters

WORD_INDEX_PATTERN = re.compile('^(.+)_(\\d+)$')¶

word_N where N is 1-based pronunciation index

create_tables(drop_existing=False, commit=True)¶

Create required database tables

property db_conn: Optional[sqlite3.Connection]¶

Get thread-local database connection

Return type

Optional[Connection]

delete_prons(word, commit=True)¶

Delete all pronuncations of a word from the database

get_best_pronunciation(token, word_prons, word_index=None)¶

Chooses the best pronunciation for a token from a list.

The method is fairly simple:

  1. If a word_index is supplied, that specific pronunciation is chosen

  2. Otherwise, the pronunciation with the most matching features is chosen

    • For example, if the token has a “NOUN” part of speech tag in its features and one word pronunciation has a matching “NOUN” value in its preferred_features, then it will be chosen

  3. Otherwise, the first pronunciation is chosen

Parameters

  • token (Token) – The token to choose a pronunciation for

  • word_prons (Sequence[WordPronunciation]) – Available pronunciations

  • word_index (Optional[int]) – Optional 1-based index of desired pronunciation

Return type

Optional[WordPronunciation]

Returns

Best pronunciation or None if one is not available

get_pronunciation(token)¶

Optional[WordPronunciation]

Return type

Returns

gruut.toksen module¶

Class for cleaning raw text and tokenizing

class gruut.toksen.RegexTokenizer(split_pattern=re.compile('\\\\s+'), join_str=' ', replacements=None, casing_func=None, punctuations=None, minor_breaks=None, major_breaks=None, abbreviations=None, number_pattern=re.compile('^(-?\\\\d+(?:[,.]\\\\d+)*)$'), number_converter_pattern=re.compile('^(-?\\\\d+(?:[,.]\\\\d+)*)_(\\\\w+)$'), non_word_pattern=re.compile('^(\\\\W|_)+$'), exclude_non_words=True, num2words_lang=None, babel_locale=None, use_number_converters=False, currency_names=None, do_replace_currency=False, currency_replacements=None, pos_model=None)¶

Bases: gruut.toksen.Tokenizer

Full-featured tokenizer with support for number expansion.

Pipline is (roughly):

  1. pre_tokenize applies regex replacements to raw text

  2. text is split using split_pattern into words

    • abbreviations are expanded, text is re-split

  3. words are split into sub-words using punctuations

    • sub-words are grouped by sentence and converted to Tokens

  4. Tokens are cleaned

    • empty and non-word tokens are dropped

    • numbers are expanded to words

    • casing_func is applied

  5. Part of speech tags are predicted (if model available)

split_pattern¶

str or re.Pattern used to split text into words

join_str¶

str used to join words back into text

replacements¶

(re.Pattern, replacement str) tuples used in pre_tokenize on text

casing_func¶

Function applied during token cleaning and abbreviation expansion (e.g., str.lower()).

punctuations¶

Single-character strings that cause words to split into sub-words. Punctuation tokens are dropped from sentence tokens unless its a major/minor break.

minor_breaks¶

Single-character strings that indicate short pauses in a sentence. Minor break tokens are kept in sentence tokens.

major_breaks¶

Single-character strings that indicate the start of a new sentence. Major break tokens are kept in sentence tokens.

abbreviations¶

Short/long form mapping. Text is resplit on whitespace after expansion. If key is a str, optional punctuation is automatically added around the pattern. If key is an re.Pattern, it must be suitable for use with re.subn() with count=1.

number_pattern¶

Pattern used to match numbers. First group must capture the number text.

number_converter_pattern¶

Pattern used to match numbers with a converter specified. For example, “2021_year” will expanded to “twenty twenty one” instead of “two thousand twenty one”. First group must capture the number text, second group the converter.

non_word_pattern¶

Pattern used to match non-words, which will be excluded from sentence tokens if exclude_non_words=True

exclude_non_words¶

Excludes non words from sentence tokens (see RegexTokenizer.is_word())

num2words_lang¶

Language for num2words number expansion (e.g., “en_US”)

babel_locale¶

Locale for babel number parsing (e.g., “en_US”)

use_number_converters¶

If True, numbers may contain converters (see number_converter_pattern).

currency_names¶

Mapping from currency symbol (e.g., “$”) to currency name (e.g., “USD”). Used by num2words during number expansion. Currency symbols are also treated as punctuation during sub-word tokenization.

do_replace_currency¶

If True, numbers after a currency symbol are converted using the num2words “currency” converter. See currency_names.

currency_replacements¶

(re.Pattern, replacement) tuples that are applied to the string returned by num2words after currency conversion. Example: “$1.50” becomes “one dollar, fifty cents”, so you may want to replace “,” with ” and “.

pos_model¶

Path to CRF part of speech tagger model. See also: gruut.pos.

NON_WORD_PATTERN = re.compile('^(\\W|_)+$')¶

Default pattern for matching non-words

NUMBER_CONVERTER_PATTERN = re.compile('^(-?\\d+(?:[,.]\\d+)*)_(\\w+)$')¶

Default pattern for matching numbers with a “converter” like “1970_year”. First group must be number text (“1970”). Second group must be converter (“year”).

NUMBER_PATTERN = re.compile('^(-?\\d+(?:[,.]\\d+)*)$')¶

Default pattern for matching numbers like 3.14. First group must be number text (“3.14”).

WHITESPACE_PATTERN = re.compile('\\s+')¶

Default pattern for initially splitting text into words

Module contents¶

gruut module

class gruut.TextToPhonemesReturn(value)¶

Bases: str, enum.Enum

Format of return value from text_to_phonemes().

FLAT_PHONEMES = 'flat_phonemes'¶

Flat list of phoneme strings

SENTENCES = 'sentences'¶

List of Sentence objects with tokens, features, etc.

SENTENCE_PHONEMES = 'sentence_phonemes'¶

Lists of phonemes grouped by sentence only

SENTENCE_WORD_PHONEMES = 'sentence_word_phonemes'¶

Lists of phonemes grouped by sentence, then word

WORD_PHONEMES = 'word_phonemes'¶

Lists of phonemes grouped by words only

WORD_TUPLES = 'word_tuples'¶

Tuples of the form (sentence index, word, word phonemes)

gruut.is_language_supported(lang)¶

True if gruut supports lang

Return type

bool

gruut.text_to_phonemes(text, lang='en-us', return_format='word_tuples', no_cache=False, tokenizer=None, tokenizer_args=None, phonemizer=None, phonemizer_args=None)¶

High-level text to phonemes interface.

Parameters

  • text (str) – Text to tokenize and phonemize

  • lang (str) – Language of the text

  • return_format (Union[str, TextToPhonemesReturn]) – Format of return value

  • no_cache (bool) – If True, tokenizer/phonemizer cache are not used

  • tokenizer (Optional[Tokenizer]) – Optional tokenizer to use instead of creating one

  • tokenizer_args (Optional[Mapping[str, Any]]) – Optional keyword arguments used when creating tokenizer

  • phonemizer (Optional[Phonemizer]) – Optional phonemizer to use instead of creating one

  • phonemizer_args (Optional[Mapping[str, Any]]) – Optional keyword arguments used when creating phonemizer

Return type

Union[List[Tuple[int, str, Sequence[str]]], List[str], List[Sequence[str]], List[List[Sequence[str]]], List[Sentence]]

Returns

Tuples of the form (sentence index, word, [word phonemes]). See TextToPhonemesReturn enum for more return formats.

Example

from gruut import text_to_phonemes

text = 'He wound it around the wound, saying "I read it was $10 to read."'

for sent_idx, word, word_phonemes in text_to_phonemes(text, lang="en-us"):
    print(word, *word_phonemes)

Output:

he h ˈi
wound w ˈaʊ n d
